passages.text: Bottom Line: Business confidence declined across all major sectors with noticeable declines in the forward- looking components. The FGV consumer confidence index declined 0.5pt in Aug to 86.2, well below the 93.3 print a year ago. The expectations declined 1.3pt to a soft 88.1 (101.6 a year ago).

1. The decline of business confidence in Aug was broad-based with notable lower readings in manufacturing (-4.4pt to 90.4; lowest since Jul-20), retail (-4.0pt to 83.1; lowest since Mar-21), services (-2.6pt to 87.1; lowest since Apr-21), and construction (-1.1pt to 91.6; lowest since Jun-21). Sentiment in retail remains the weakest among the main economic sectors, followed by services.

2. Across all four main sectors, the decline of the forward-looking business expectations component was larger than the drop of the current conditions index: -6.4/-4.9/-4.1/-1.6pt in retail/manufacturing/services/construction.

3. The FGV consumer confidence index declined 0.5pt in Aug to 86.2, well below the 93.3 reading a year ago. The component measuring current conditions rose 1.1pt to 84.5, but the expectations component declined 1.3pt to 88.1.
Tomorrow: Consolidated Public Sector Primary Fiscal balance (Jul); we forecast a R\$60bn deficit, vs R\$21.3bn deficit a year ago.

On a 12- month rolling basis, the overall public sector fiscal deficit (primary surplus minus net interest payments) is tracking at 7.3% of GDP, with the net interest bill at 7.45% of GDP (up slightly from 7.39% of GDP a year ago).

The stock of gross general government debt is tracking at 76.6% of GDP (+50bp from May ago up from 71.7% at end- 22) [89.9% of GDP according to the IMF standard definition which includes central bank holdings of freely usable government debt instruments]. The stock of net public sector debt rose 90bp to 62.9% of GDP (56.1% of GDP at end- 22).

Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Tomorrow: Unemployment Rate (July); we expect a 0.2pp rise in the unemployment rate to \(9.1\%\) . In our assessment, the labor market remains soft and the June's labor market report was weak. The unemployment rate was unchanged at \(8.9\%\) in June due to lower participation, despite falling employment levels. July is also affected by unfavorable seasonal factors that typically result in a higher unemployment rate.

Tomorrow: Retail Sales (July); we forecast a \(6.7\%\) yoy increase in retail sales in July. Our year- on- year forecast is consistent with retail sales declining in July (month- on- month) after the June print \((+3.4\%)\) mom sa) reflected a strong performance of sales around the Cyber day campaign held June 2- 4.

Tomorrow: Manufacturing Production (July); we forecast a \(3.0\%\) expansion of manufacturing output in July. Manufacturing activity printed a solid reading in June with activity rising \(12.0\%\) yoy \((+1.7\%)\) mom) with the food industry adding a notable 5.4pp to the headline print \((+17.8\%)\) .

Bottom Line: The unemployment rate declined further in July. The unemployment rate dropped to \(2.77\%\) in July, below Bloomberg consensus and the \(2.93\%\) print a year ago. Seasonally adjusted, the unemployment rate declined 6bp to a tight \(2.56\%\) \((+11bp\) from the Oct- 24 record low). A broad measure of unemployment (which considers the individuals outside the labor force but available to work if offered a job) is tracking at \(10.1\%\) , down from \(10.6\%\) a year ago. The labor force participation rate declined 30bp to \(59.6\%\) sa (- 90bp from a year ago). Employment rose \(0.8\%\) yoy, with salaried jobs down \(0.6\%\) yoy (self- employment rose \(1.4\%\) yoy). The underemployment rate declined 20bp to \(70\%\) sa and the rate of informality jumped 90bp to \(55.7\%\) sa. According to the Social Security Ministry Registry (IMSS), formal employment declined \(0.1\%\) yoy in July (excluding digital platform workers), down from \(2.0\%\) yoy a year ago and \(1.0\%\) at end- 2024. Formal employment peaked in Jan- 25. Going forward we expect below- trend real activity growth to impact labor market conditions.

1. The unemployment rate printed at \(2.77\%\) in July, below the Bloomberg consensus \((2.86\%)\) and the \(2.93\%\) print a year ago. On a seasonal and calendar adjusted basis the unemployment rate declined 6bp to a tight \(2.56\%\) . 
2. A broad measure of unemployment printed at \(10.1\%\) , down from \(10.6\%\) a year ago and below the \(13.7\%\) pre-pandemic historical average; this measure takes into consideration the cohort classified as outside the labor force (did not work and did not look for a job) but available to work if offered a job.

3. An estimated \(5.09\mathrm{mn}\) individual of working age were classified as outside the active labor force (did not work and did not look for a job) but were available to work (down from \(5.34\mathrm{mn}\) a year ago). This contingent is equivalent to \(12.3\%\) of the working age population outside the labor force.

4. Compared with the same month a year ago, employment rose by \(0.48\mathrm{mn}\) \((+0.8\%\) yoy), and the economically active population rose \(0.39\mathrm{mn}\) \((+0.6\%\) yoy). Hence, the ranks of the unemployed declined \(0.09\mathrm{mn}\) to \(1.73\mathrm{mn}\) .
5. Labor force participation declined \(30\mathrm{bp}\) to \(59.6\%\) sa \((-90\mathrm{bp}\) from a year ago).

6. Salaried employment declined \(0.6\%\) yoy in July \((+0.5\%\) yoy in June) and self-employment rose \(1.4\%\) yoy. Employment in manufacturing rose \(1.5\%\) yoy but in construction declined \(3.9\%\) yoy. Employment in retail rose \(2.3\%\) yoy and in services \(2.7\%\) yoy.
7. Underemployment (those reporting the need and availability to work more hours than their current job) declined \(20\mathrm{bp}\) to \(7.0\%\) sa.
8. The rate of informality rose \(90\mathrm{bp}\) to \(55.7\%\) sa \((+160\mathrm{bp}\) from a year ago) of the employed labor force.

9. According to the Social Security Ministry Registry (IMSS), formal employment declined \(0.1\%\) yoy in July (excluding digital platform workers), down from \(2.0\%\) yoy a year ago and \(1.0\%\) at end-2024. Formal employment peaked in Jan-25.
Tomorrow: Quarterly Inflation Report (2Q25).
Tomorrow: Bank Lending (Jul); bank credit decelerated to \(5.2\%\) yoy in real terms in Jun (vs \(7.3\%\) yoy in May).

In real terms, consumer lending expanded \(8.9\%\) yoy \((0.3\%\) mom sa) in Jun, vs. \(8.8\%\) yoy \((0.4\%\) mom sa) in May. Corporate credit softened: \(5.4\%\) yoy \((- 1.2\%\) mom sa), vs. \(9.2\%\) yoy \((0.8\%\) mom sa) in May.

This research is for our clients only. Goldman Sachs conducts a global full- service, integrated investment banking, investment management, and brokerage business. LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

Our salespeople, traders, and other professionals may provide oral or written market commentary or trading strategies to our clients and principal trading desks that reflect opinions that are contrary to the opinions expressed in this research. Our asset management area, principal trading desks and investing businesses may make investment decisions that are inconsistent with the recommendations or views expressed in this research.

We and our affiliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character-risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.
